title: Rheumatology in the digital health era: status quo and quo vadis?
abstract: Rheumatology faces a critical shortage of health-care professionals, exacerbated by an ageing patient population and escalating costs, resulting in widening gaps in care. Exponential advances in digital health technologies (DHTs) in the past 5 years offer new opportunities to address these challenges and could contribute to overall improved health care. However, keeping pace with innovations and integrating them into clinical practice can be challenging. This Review explores the transformative potential of DHTs for rheumatology in reshaping the entire patient pathway and redefining the roles of patients and providers, and discusses the potential barriers to DHT integration. Key technologies, such as large language models, clinical decision-support systems, digital therapeutics, electronic patient-reported outcomes, digital biomarkers, robots, self-sampling devices and artificial intelligence-based scribes, can be implemented along the patient pathway. A digital-first hybrid stepped-care patient pathway could combine in-person and remote care, enabling personalized and continuous monitoring through a digital safety net. The potential benefits and risks of transforming the traditional patientprovider relationship into a digital health triad with technology are discussed. Collaborative efforts are needed to navigate the evolving digital health landscape and harness the potential of DHTs to improve rheumatology care.

The integration of DHTs across the entire patient pathway (Fig.  1 ) has the potential to contribute to achieving the overarching quadruple aims of health care: reducing costs, improving population health, and enhancing both patient and provider experience  3  .

sections.title: Digitally supported diagnosis
sections.text: Diagnosis can often be delayed by months and numerous preceding physician visits. Despite various efforts, improvements in triage efficiency have been minimal and only a minority of patients presenting to rheumatologists are ultimately diagnosed with an inflammatory rheumatic disease  4, 5  .

sections.title: Data mining for improved identification of individuals at risk
sections.text: Ideally, individuals at risk of and patients with rheumatic diseases could be identified early by using their existing medical information, primarily stored in electronic health records. Data mining algorithms can extract meaningful information from the unstructured data within electronic health records, which aids the identification process. However, the efficacy of these algorithms varies widely, with results ranging from highly promising  6  to modest in real-world settings  7  owing to low disease incidence.

sections.title: Patient-facing diagnostic decision-support systems
sections.text: Individuals first presenting with symptoms are increasingly opting for a digital-first approach, whereby individuals first assess their symptoms online and use dedicated patient-facing diagnostic decision-support systems (DDSSs) such as symptom checkers  8, 9  . Symptom checkers offer standardized symptom assessments and are accessible anywhere and anytime, providing disease suggestions and recommended actions on the basis of the input provided. Although symptom checkers are well received, their diagnostic accuracy remains limited  5, 9, 10  , ranging between 52% and 63% in a first multicentre evaluation study  5  . Data from one study showed that only 14% of experienced rheumatologists could provide an accurate diagnosis of inflammatory rheumatic diseases on the basis of medical history alone  11  . To address these limitations, symptom checkers could be improved by integrating additional objective data alongside subjective symptoms in order to enhance diagnostic accuracy and enable cross-verification. The true value of symptom checkers could be their capacity to streamline automated history taking, thereby saving time and allowing for more in-depth, future patient-clinician dialogue. The incorporation of AI-based software, including LLMs, can further augment traditional history taking. LLMs have demonstrated the ability to detect subtle nuances in pain expression, which can be particularly effective in identifying conditions such as fibromyalgia  12  . A preliminary study found that an AI-based symptom checker could make the correct diagnosis more frequently (54% versus 32%) than rheumatologists (the information given to clinicians was limited to basic health and symptom-related medical history)  13  . In a direct comparison using the same patient vignettes from the previous study, the LLM ChatGPT-4 listed the correct diagnosis as one the top possibilities at a rate comparable to rheumatologists (35% versus 39%)  14  .

sections.title: Introduction
sections.text:
The growing scarcity of rheumatologists, escalating costs and ageing of the patient population exacerbate the strain on health-care systems and accentuate existing care deficits. The assessment of often unspecific but potentially rheumatic symptoms is characterized by prolonged waiting times for specialist consultations, causing irreversible damage accrual and diminished cost-effective treatment options. Despite new promising therapeutic approaches, conventional treatment is largely dominated by a trial-and-error and non-personalized approach. Patient monitoring seems inflexible, incomplete and limited to brief, burdensome periodic face-to-face consultations. The lack of a comprehensive picture of disease activity, lack of decision support and a disjointed flow of information often results in duplicative efforts and can substantially influence health outcomes.

In the pursuit of bridging these care gaps, digital health enables enhanced, continuous and flexible patient care that can broadly be defined as "the convergence of science and technology with health, health care, living, and society" 1 . Since the COVID-19 pandemic started, the number of available tools and corresponding literature has seen an unprecedented increase, making it hard to stay up to date.

In this Review, we depict the potential and barriers of digital health technologies (DHTs) in enhancing the diagnosis, treatment and monitoring of patients with rheumatic diseases. Additionally, we examine the implications of DHTs for rheumatology education and research. Key technologies, such as large language models (LLMs), clinical decision-support systems, digital therapeutics, electronic patient-reported outcomes (ePROs), wearables, robots, patient self-sampling devices and artificial intelligence (AI)-based scribes, are examined. We outline an anticipated vision of a digital-first hybrid stepped-care patient pathway. The integration of DHTs could improve access to care, foster evidence-based medicine and catalyse a shift

sections.text: information is available  15, 16  . DDSSs are tailored for professional use, provide support and often incorporate broader data sets, including laboratory and imaging results, which enhances diagnostic precision. The potential of DDSS-aided diagnosis is not new and the discussion around this topic started more than three decades ago  17  . Yet, despite the increasing number of DDSSs for rheumatology, integration into clinical practice remains limited  18  . Using DDSSs to assist with diagnosis can enhance physician accuracy without demanding extra time or reducing patient satisfaction  19, 20  and could also reduce time to diagnosis for several rare rheumatic diseases (such as antisynthetase syndrome and Felty syndrome)  21  . Isabel  22  and FindZebra  23  are examples of DDSSs that are designed for the diagnosis of rare diseases. Furthermore, integrating DDSSs into the rheumatology diagnostic process could help ensure that no potential diagnoses are missed. Critical evaluation of DDSS output is crucial to avoid the blind adoption of potentially erroneous suggestions  24  . LLMs are becoming increasingly powerful DDSSs, capable of interpreting multimodal data, including images, videos, laboratory results and previous medical reports  25, 26  . Interaction with LLM chatbots is more user-friendly compared to traditional DDSSs, enabling clinicians to pose custom queries, such as 'Is this patient more likely to suffer from antisynthetase syndrome or inclusion body myositis and why?'. Although the diagnostic accuracy of LLMs is still limited, this type of DDSS could aid physicians, especially in the diagnosis of rare diseases as shown in a preprint published in 2024 (ref. 27).

sections.title: Patient self-sampling
sections.text: The decentralization of diagnostic assessments through home-use capillary self-sampling devices has gained acceptance  8, 28, 29  because of the convenience and cost-effectiveness of these devices, with devices for upper-arm sampling preferred by patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) due to less discomfort compared with finger-prick methods  29  . Although asking patients to provide information from home (such as medical history taking and self-sampling) has only become more regular in rheumatology since the COVID-19 pandemic, decentralized remote diagnostic assessments have been commonly used in other areas for some time such as in the diagnosis of sexually transmitted diseases  30  . A 2023 pilot study demonstrated that combining data collection at home with supervised student-led clinics created an effective hybrid approach, enabling accelerated diagnoses and timely treatment initiation in patients with suspected axial spondyloarthritis  31  .

sections.title: Automation of diagnostic procedures
sections.text: The automation of diagnostic procedures, such as ultrasonography exams with robotic and AI assistance  32  , promises to enhance access, reduce variability and minimize the need for direct HCP involvement. Imaging is one of the first areas to harness the benefits of AI, with heatmaps guiding HCPs in objective detection and grading of pathology, including the use of conventional radiographs  33  and nailfold capillary images  34  .

sections.title: Digitally supported treatment
sections.text: Although the introduction of targeted therapies has marked a substantial advancement, the effectiveness of these therapies seems to be constrained by a glass ceiling. The ideal treatment paradigm adheres to P4 medicine -predictive, preventive, personalized and participatory  2  . Digital treatment support for patients and HCPs offers a promising approach to achieve P4 medicine.

sections.title: Synchronous and asynchronous communication
sections.text: Digitally supported patient communication can be divided into synchronous  35  and asynchronous  36  . Traditional synchronous communication occurs in real time and includes traditional on-site face-to-face consultation as well as video-consultations and phone calls. sections.title: Digitally supported self-management
sections.text:
We envision that the digital transformation will drastically alter information gathering and care delivery (Fig.  2 ). DHTs empower patients to autonomously collect, interpret and act on medical information, thereby catalysing effective self-management. Digitally supported patient self-management could contribute to overcoming care gaps while simultaneously alleviating the burden on the health-care system. This shift towards patient self-management exemplifies the increasing democratization of care, thereby mitigating information asymmetry and diminishing medical paternalism. Augmented patient autonomy and decentralized care delivery might reduce the current burden of care by alleviating constraints such as travel time, costs and response time.

Insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus provides an example of advanced technology-supported self-management, whereby patients use continuous glucose monitors and automated insulin delivery systems to safely and effectively improve the percentage of time that individuals with diabetes stay within their target blood sugar range  37  . Creating a closed-loop system for patients with rheumatic diseases is still at the early stages of development. Nonetheless, a study assessed a wearable device that was capable of detecting inflammation via impedance sensing in Sprague-Dawley male rats; upon detection, the device initiated a synergistic treatment regimen combining subcutaneous methotrexate and electrical stimulation  38  . The promising results observed in this preclinical model warrant further investigation to evaluate the potential of such advanced technologies in clinical applications.

sections.title: Digital patient education
sections.text:
The recommended general patient education to promote self-management  39  is severely limited by staff shortages and financial pressures. A patient survey carried out in 2022 revealed that only 24% of patients rated their level of disease education as very good or good  40  .

Of these patients, 89% said that they would welcome digital education tools to learn about their condition; however, validated online education programmes are currently scarce. A randomized controlled trial carried out in 2024 demonstrated substantially higher self-efficacy and similar knowledge, health literacy and quality of life in patients who completed an online education course compared with face-to-face education  41  . However, patients typically have to search for information themselves and older patients in particular have limited access to online health education resources and can struggle to find valid information  42  . The ongoing expansion of digital information makes it increasingly challenging to distinguish between reliable and misleading content, as the volume and pace of changes continue to grow. The brief nature of doctor visits often limits effective advice regarding disease management, leaving many patient questions unanswered. LLM-based chatbots could provide patients with access to answers to a lot of their questions and are always available. Preliminary studies that assessed ChatGTP responses to questions from patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) yielded promising results, indicating that ChatGPT responses were often deemed of higher quality and more empathetic than those from SLE experts, according to both specialists and patients  43, 44  . To achieve clinical implementation, rigorous validation, along with the assurance of data privacy and security, must be accomplished  45  .

sections.title: Digital therapeutics
sections.text: Access to non-pharmacological treatments, such as physiotherapy and psychotherapy, can be hindered by the scarcity of HCPs and the considerable distances often involved in travelling to appointments. Video-consultations help to break down geographical barriers and improve patient access to care, often demonstrating comparable treatment effects. Digital therapeutics have the potential to address geographical, temporal and capacity-related barriers by providing automated, evidence-based treatment options that are accessible at any time and location. Core osteoarthritis management strategies (such as patient education, exercise, physical activity and dietary weight management) might be effectively supported by digital therapeutics. A landmark multicentre trial this year demonstrated the non-inferiority of physiotherapy delivered by video-consultations compared to in-person care for chronic knee and back pain  46, 47  . Back pain digital therapeutics showed a greater reduction in pain compared to the gold standard of face-to-face physiotherapy, likely owing to patients exercising more frequently with the aid of their smartphones at home  47  . The level of guidance for digital therapeutic-based physiotherapy varies from simple video instructions to motion capture-based  47  or wearable-based real-time tracking and feedback. Preliminary evidence suggests that digital therapeutics can effectively support patients with inflammatory rheumatic diseases, including axial spondyloarthritis (axSpA)  48, 49  .

sections.title: Review article
sections.text: A phase III clinical trial carried out this year demonstrated both the effectiveness and safety of app-based psychological acceptance and commitment therapy in patients with fibromyalgia  50  . Virtual reality-based digital therapeutics offer a valuable complementary treatment option for patients with fibromyalgia, with notable increases in pain thresholds and pain tolerance  51  . Digital therapeutics could provide general disease-specific lifestyle recommendations  52  and addressed particular comorbidities such as depression, diabetes, weight reduction, smoking cessation and sleep disorders. Well-known therapy barriers also exist with digital forms of therapy. A real-world rheumatology registry study confirmed low adherence as a main barrier to the effectiveness of digital health products, with only 13% of patients completing the full digital therapeutics programme over a 3-month period  49  . The study revealed that older men in particular were less likely to use digital therapeutics. Given the availability of immediate, standardized therapeutic options, we foresee an increase in the adoption of digital-first strategies that will help to reduce waiting times and bridge growing gaps in care.

sections.title: Clinical decision-support systems
sections.text: Current treatment largely follows a reactive trial-and-error strategy, which fails to deliver quick and enduring benefits to many patients. Harnessing AI seems promising to predict individual treatment responses, guide treatment choices  53, 54  , and further reduce drug development costs and time  55  . Simple, yet effective, tools such as medication reminders aid patient adherence to treatment and prevent the waste of health-care resources  56  . As patients achieve disease remission, AI-enhanced clinical decision-support systems could assist in safely tapering treatments. These systems could help minimize deviations from treatment protocols and bolster the confidence of rheumatologists in making informed treatment decisions  57  . The ability to 'ask' LLMs for treatment recommendations through straightforward queries such as 'How should I treat this patient?' could facilitate the translation of complex clinical guidelines into practical, actionable personalized recommendations. A 2024 study demonstrated that ChatGPT was capable of generating safe and high-quality treatment plans for the majority of included patients with rheumatic diseases based on such simple queries  58  .

sections.title: Digitally supported patient monitoring
sections.text: Patient follow-up consists of periodic pre-planned face-to-face consultations resulting in suboptimal use of HCP and patient time and resources. This traditional approach leads to frequent, unnecessary clinical visits without adjustments to treatment, while changes in disease activity between appointments often go unnoticed, resulting in missed opportunities for treatment optimization. The conventional patient follow-up approach seems outdated, not based on patient needs and not flexible enough to enable a steady assessment of new patients and continuous follow-up care. Patient-initiated follow-up is a care delivery model in which patients reach out to the clinic as needed, rather than attending regularly scheduled follow-ups. This model is currently mainly used for patients with less complex diseases and stable disease activity  [59] [60] [61] [62]  . Incorporating digital health could enhance safety, ensure continuity of care and support this proactive, patient-centred and need-adapted approach to patient follow-up  63  . A shift towards remote care not only reduces the burden for patients with low disease activity but also frees up capacity to treat new patients and those with severe, active disease. Additionally, remote care holds the potential to enhance the work experience of HCPs, many of whom face long commutes and appreciate the increased flexibility to balance work and family life.

sections.title: Electronic patient-reported outcomes
sections.text: ePROs are a cornerstone in monitoring individuals with rheumatic disease and can also be used in between planned visits to detect disease fluctuations and to inform treatment changes and the necessity for face-to-face visits. However, ePROs should not constantly remind patients of their disease and frequency should be tailored to disease activity  64  . Discussing monitoring data with patients enhances patient-provider interactions  65  ; however, many rheumatologists are concerned about the additional time required to review and discuss these data  66  . ePROs can be used effectively to streamline and prioritize face-to-face appointments. Weekly smartphone-based monitoring with the Routine Assessment of Patient Index Data 3 (RAPID3) led to a 38% decrease in rheumatologist consultations for patients with RA and lowered health-care costs whilst maintaining stable patient disease activity  67, 68  . An ePRO-based remote monitoring pathway for patients with RA was successfully implemented in 2020 (ref. 60) (Box 1).

sections.title: Digital biomarkers
sections.text: Smartphones increasingly enable patients to independently collect medical data that goes far beyond traditional questionnaires and conduct their own objective assessments, enabling the automated detection and quantification of swollen joints  69  , handgrip strength  70  , nail psoriasis  71  and range of motion  72  . The wear study currently aims to investigate a more comprehensive monitoring approach, including wearable data and traditional ePROs  73  .

sections.title: Box 1 | Successful implementation of remote monitoring for rheumatoid arthritis
sections.text: In mid-2020, the Southmead rheumatology department introduced a remote monitoring pathway for patients with rheumatoid arthritis on biologic or targeted synthetic disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs  60  . As part of this pathway, patients were offered a smartphone app to complete electronic patient-reported outcomes (Routine Assessment of Patient Index Data 3 (RAPID3), Health Assessment Questionnaire-Disability Index and self-reported Disease Activity Score-28 for Rheumatoid Arthritis using C-reactive protein), which clinicians reviewed asynchronously via a web-based portal. Clinicians then sent letters to patients in remission with satisfactory and up-to-date blood monitoring data summarizing the review. Reviews were conducted either at the default 6-month interval or sooner if requested by a clinician or patient (expedited review). Face-to-face appointments were available as needed (escalated review) and an in-person review was required every 3 years. Within the first year, this initiative saved over 140 h of clinic time and approximately £80,000 in unnecessary appointment costs. Patient surveys indicated high satisfaction, with more than 90% of patients expressing a preference to continue with non-face-to-face appointments. By mid-2023, the programme had enrolled over 1,100 patients and completed more than 40,000 electronic patient-reported outcomes.

sections.text: whilst generating abundant data; however, research regarding passive monitoring of patients with rheumatic diseases is limited and heterogeneous  74, 75  . Wristwatch tracking of physical activity has proven effective in accurately predicting disease flares in patients with RA and axSpA  76  . Additionally, physical activity metrics show promise for less common conditions such as myositis, aligning closely with established physical tests and treatment response criteria  77  . Sleep behaviour monitoring further refines patient profiles, offering a basis for highly personalized and automated behaviour change recommendations  78  . Although self-sampling presents opportunities to predict disease flares  79, 80  , the high frequency and cost of individual blood collections remain challenging  28  . Advances in continuous, passive and non-invasive biomarker monitoring could transform rheumatology, similar to the effect of continuous glucose monitoring in diabetes management. Emerging technologies such as wireless patches for measuring C-reactive protein (CRP) in sweat  81  and salivary uric acid  82  to closed-loop systems  38  , highlight future potential in the field  82  .

sections.title: Towards a digital-first hybrid stepped-care model
sections.text: In line with evolving trends in diagnosis and treatment, we anticipate a shift towards a more flexible, digital-first, hybrid stepped-care model, which incorporates five levels of monitoring (Fig.  3 ). At the core is a digital safety net based on passive, continuous sensor-based monitoring (level 1) and on-demand self-assessments (level 2), where AI models can provide instant automated feedback to patients and trigger monitoring alerts for HCPs. Monitoring alarms and chat-based queries can trigger virtual visits (level 3) and asynchronous feedback by HCPs. Virtual visits to review RA flare questionnaires and CRP results by nurses or rheumatologists every 3-4 months enabled a safe reduction of face-to-face visits  83, 84  . Notably, no differences were observed between rheumatology nurses or rheumatologists performing the remote monitoring of patients. A similar study in patients with axSpA investigated a fully remote approach, incorporating self-sampling to remotely generate an Ankylosing Spondylitis Disease Activity Score with CRP, which was reviewed in conjunction with more frequent questionnaires (Bath Ankylosing Spondylitis Disease Activity Index and Patient Global Assessment of Disease Activity bi-weekly and weekly flare questionnaire). This approach facilitated a safe reduction in face-toface visits and was highly accepted by patients  85  . Two large randomized controlled trials are currently under way to assess the efficacy of remote monitoring in patients with axSpA  62, 86  . Remote monitoring might also foster a treat-to-target approach and accelerate disease remission. Monthly or bi-monthly virtual visits to assess Rheumatoid Arthritis Impact of Disease questionnaire results, along with standardized treatment intensification, significantly increased the proportion of patients with early RA achieving Clinical Disease Activity Index remission  87  . Similarly, virtual visits have also been effectively implemented to improve the attainment of urate targets in patients with gout  88, 89  . The ongoing TELERA trial assesses treatment concordance of asynchronous virtual visits compared to traditional in-person visits in patients with RA  90  .

sections.title: Level 4
sections.text: Video-consultations In traditional follow-up, patients attend synchronous, periodic, pre-planned, face-to-face consultations, which can result in overlooked disease flares and adverse effects. Quick access to answers and appointments during flares is challenging. Conversely, digitally supported hybrid patient follow-up fosters a proactive, continuous and personalized care approach. We anticipate a transition towards a digital-first stepped-care monitoring approach. Passive continuous monitoring via sensors (level 1) and on-demand self-assessments (level 2) establish a foundational digital safety net. If queries cannot be solved using automated feedback, health-care professionals are prompted by monitoring alarms to perform virtual visits (level 3). If queries cannot be resolved on the first three asynchronous levels, monitoring is escalated to the synchronous approach (video-consultation, telephone, chat; level 4) and traditional face-to-face appointments (level 5) are only arranged as a last resort.

sections.title: Review article
sections.text: The next monitoring escalation (level 4) would involve synchronous remote communication, including telephone calls and video-consultations. During the COVID-19 pandemic, the use of video-consultations increased; however, virtual examinations are still developing and have not yet reached full maturity  91  . Video-consultations demonstrated a substantial reliability in identifying patients that required treatment adjustments  92  . In line with previous results  59  , a randomized controlled trial demonstrated that for more complex diseases, such as SLE, monitoring often had to be escalated to face-to-face visits. We anticipate that face-to-face consultations (level 5) will be notably reduced, representing the final escalation in monitoring. Moreover, face-to-face care will likely predominantly involve patients with complex refractory diseases and high disease activity  59  , with successfully treated patients being mostly monitored virtually. This shift could also lead to an increase in rheumatologists providing a combination of in-person and remote care. This combination could facilitate a sustainable balance between in-person treatment of patients with highly complex and active disease with the remote management of a higher number of patients who are in remission.

sections.title: Augmented in-person visits
sections.text: Physical examinations face challenges such as substantial diurnal symptom variation  93  , time constraints and inter-rater variability. Digital technologies enhance the objectivity of these examinations, possibly also rendering traditional functional capacity questionnaires obsolete. Measurement of spinal mobility is, for example, heavily affected by variability and subjectivity. Automated motion capture systems, such as the University of Cordoba Ankylosing Spondylitis Metrology Index, provide precise and objective assessments  94  . Medical documentation could be immensely facilitated by artificial intelligence-powered ambient virtual scribes such as Ambience or Nuance DAX, which instantly generate structured summaries of patient-provider interactions. A first real-world pilot study revealed a statistically significant yet clinically negligible average time-saving effect of less than 1 min per patient  95  ; however, this technology does enable physicians to redirect their attention from screens to patients  95, 96  . Greater integration of LLMs into clinical workflows can also help to improve other administrative tasks such as appointment scheduling and correspondence with insurance companies.

sections.title: Research and clinical trials
sections.text:
Reviewing the scientific literature can be a time-consuming process. Free tools such as AI-based Elicit can streamline this task by allowing straightforward questions, such as 'Is remote monitoring safe for patients with rheumatic diseases?', to be asked. Short summaries of the literature and customizable overviews of the research make it easier to gain insights efficiently. Rheumatology research is often held back by slow and expensive clinical trials, fragmentation of data and siloed research teams. Decentralized clinical trials can facilitate patient recruitment by eliminating the need for travel and reducing patient burden and costs  97, 98  . The increasing online presence of patient support groups has furthered patient recruitment, co-design between patients and HCPs, and overall patient involvement in research projects. Collaborative online studies offer a new frontier in medical research (particularly for rare diseases) by facilitating large-scale, patient-focused research that integrates patient perspectives as equal stakeholders and valued partners in the study of their conditions, ultimately improving clinical care  99  . This approach could be particularly valuable for individuals with rare diseases who are faced with unforeseen circumstances such as establishing the safety of vaccines during a global pandemic 100 .

Remote monitoring technology leverages outcome assessments and enables rich trial data. Free but powerful web applications, such as REDCap, bring patient cohorts together and generate new clinical knowledge, for example, the reliability of antisynthetase antibodies 101 . Disease activity scoring is often a tedious, labour-intensive task, which requires special training and often results in deviating scores due to high inter-rater reliability. AI promises to overcome these limitations, even in rare diseases. A study evaluated the performance of the LLM Claude-2 in assessing disease severity in idiopathic inflammatory myopathies using the Myositis Disease Activity Assessment Tool-Visual Analogue Scale, compared with the scores of three human assessors. The results showed good reliability between Claude-2 and human assessors, with an average intraclass correlation coefficient of 0.93 (95% CI 0.92-0.94) and strong positive correlations between the global assessment of Claude-2 scores and those of experienced assessors. The Claude-2-generated scores were on par with those of skilled assessors and outperformed inexperienced scorers 102 . Hence, this tool could be used to accelerate the identification of patients with severe disease while negating the need to scan records for suitable participants and potentially to manually rate disease activity.

sections.title: Training and education
sections.text: Digitalization has opened a new frontier in educational approaches  103  . Wider outreach has brought hope of reducing inequities, overcoming geographical barriers and fostering collaborative learning. Social media fosters the formation of an interconnected digital community 104 . To this effect, RheumMadness, a bracket-style online competition, featuring rheumatology concepts as 'teams', fostered a community of enquiry through social media discussions, multimedia resources and prediction brackets, facilitating social constructivist learning about the field. The programme expanded its participant base and engagement from 2021 to 2022, particularly among early learners who credited the programme for increasing their interest in rheumatology and fostering a sense of belonging in the rheumatology community through the collaborative learning approach 105 . Educational content can be delivered more vividly compared to traditional textbooks using new technologies such as virtual reality 106 and chatbots  24  , facilitating the training of HCPs and increasing the interest of medical students in rheumatology  106  . LLMs represent a paradigm shift in medical education by offering on-demand, flexible tutoring that enables queries such as 'What are the typical symptoms of antisynthetase syndrome?'. Blended learning approaches, similar to hybrid care (also known as blended care), combine the strengths of face-to-face and digital learning environments, allowing greater flexibility, and are particularly useful for teaching practical skills such as ultrasound  107  .

sections.title: DHT implementation barriers
sections.text: The successful deployment of DHTs is offset by numerous barriers 108 . HCPs could feel overwhelmed by the need to review constant streams of monitoring data  66  and to integrate technology troubleshooting tasks into their schedules. To address this, the introduction of specialized care members, such as digital navigators 109 , might be necessary to effectively implement technology into clinical routines. Education has a key role in overcoming resistance and scepticism  8, 110  , providing the necessary knowledge and awareness to facilitate widespread adoption of these technologies. DHTs are still rarely integrated into student and professional curricula, which hinders widespread adoption 111 . To fully

sections.title: Review article
sections.text: harness the potential of LLMs, HCPs will need to develop entirely new skills, including LLM prompt engineering 112 . Refined and precise LLM instructions could facilitate several clinical and academic tasks such as generating differential diagnosis or writing grant applications. The current scarcity of evidence supporting DHT implementation must be addressed urgently to provide solid facts that can reassure sceptical colleagues and policy-makers 113 . Dedicated funding of digital health research and DHT reimbursement is also crucial to fostering implementation into routine care. Rheumatologists are unlikely to adopt remote care if video-consultations and virtual visits result in net losses. The USA billing codes for remote therapeutic monitoring provide a model for incentivising such services. Similarly, German legislation has introduced Digitale Gesundheitsanwendungen (DiGA), regulated digital health applications that can be prescribed by physicians and are fully reimbursed. Implementation of a pay-for-performance for digital therapeutics approach could foster digital therapeutics cost-effectiveness 114 . Digital therapeutics are well suited for a pay-for-performance model, as adherence and effectiveness data can be easily monitored remotely. This enables insurance companies to reimburse digital therapeutic interventions based on their demonstrated outcomes, ensuring cost-efficiency and preventing unnecessary expenditures.

sections.title: Digital divide
sections.text: Addressing infrastructural challenges, such as limited internet access and interoperability issues, requires considerable patience and persistence 110 . To truly close care gaps and avoid exacerbating the digital divide, it is crucial that special attention is given to vulnerable individuals. Shifting tasks and responsibilities to patients imposes new demands on those who are ill and should only be done voluntarily, with careful consideration given to preventing overwhelm, anxiety and the potential for medical errors  115  . The World Health Organization recommends dedicated training and quality assurance mechanisms to ensure safe and effective task shifting  116  . It is important to recognize that patient preferences can vary widely, with some individuals favouring traditional, physician-led care over an increased emphasis on self-management.

sections.title: Balancing benefits and risk of AI implementation
sections.text:
The increasing integration of AI models will likely transform the traditional patient-provider relationship into a digital health triad (Fig.  4 ). Medical data collected by both patients and HCPs will be stored in data lakes (centralized repositories that store vast amounts of raw data) and AI models will constantly generate decision-support data and utilize this data for continuous model improvement. However, the effect of AI can be double-edged and potential risks need to be considered such as AI bias, blind trust in AI recommendations and the danger of AI paternalism, where HCPs and patients have to justify decisions that diverge from AI-generated suggestions 117 . The performance of LLMs is constrained because of limited access to large, high-quality medical data sets for training  26  . To mitigate algorithmic biases, which frequently result from models trained on small, homogeneous patient populations, it is essential to include participants from diverse backgrounds 118 . The factuality and safety of LLMs can be improved by the restructuring of clinical queries into 'search' and 'retrieval' tasks and subsequent knowledge distillation (performed by the LLMs) from the retrieved documents  119  .

Ensuring data privacy, security and transparency in data usage and algorithms is essential, and regulators must carefully balance fostering innovation with maintaining these standards 120 . The EU Artificial Intelligence Act, the world's first comprehensive legal framework specifically addressing AI, has a pivotal role in guaranteeing the safe and ethical use of AI. However, this legislation also introduces greater complexity and costs, which are likely to disproportionately affect smaller enterprises, including those offering open-source products, potentially weakening their market position  45  . Moreover, the rapid evolution of the AI health-care market and the lack of regulatory enforcement in the European Union and USA raise doubts about the actual influence of any regulations  120  . Utilizing open-source LLMs (such as Llama) on local hardware could help to overcome the security challenges associated with using privately controlled, cloud-based LLMs such as ChatGPT-4 (ref. 121).

sections.title: Implementation guidance
sections.text:
Despite the considerable potential of DHTs, failure to adopt and premature discontinuation are extremely common  66, 122, 123  ; however, frameworks, checklists and guidelines can support successful implementation  111, [124] [125] [126] [127] [128] [129] [130] [131] [132] [133] [134]  . The Nonadoption, Abandonment, Scale-up, Spread, and Sustainability (NASSS) framework 127 is particularly useful for planning the implementation and scale-up of DHTs. This framework can also inform the design and evaluation of existing DHTs, providing insight into the reasons behind implementation failures. The NASSS framework comprises 13 questions across six domains (Fig.  5 ): the condition; the technology; the value proposition; the adopter system (including staff and patients); the health-care organization; and the broader institutional and societal context 127 . An additional seventh domain addresses adaptations over time. To facilitate continuous, iterative adaptations, the Plan-Do-Check-Act cycle, which was introduced in the 1950s, serves as a valuable complement to the NASSS framework. In addition, the 42-item telehealth development and implementation checklist 128 could be a useful tool for implementation. This list encompasses six key components: identifying issues, needs and partners; developing a strategy; securing funding; implementing service delivery changes; monitoring and evaluation; and leadership and training.

Change management 129 is especially valuable in consolidating DHT implementation. Although various change management models exist, the Balanced Scorecard 130 is particularly effective in providing strategic insights; this scorecard embraces key performance indicators, such as the number of remotely monitored patients, to monitor success and guide iterative improvements.

sections.title: Glossary
sections.text: Artificial intelligence-powered ambient virtual scribes Automated systems that use artificial intelligence (AI) to passively listen to and transcribe doctor-patient interactions in real time, reducing the documentation burden on health-care professionals.

sections.title: Balanced Scorecard
sections.text: A strategic management tool that tracks the performance of an organization across multiple perspectives to provide a comprehensive view of the progress made towards achieving the objectives of the organization.

sections.title: Blended learning
sections.text: An educational approach that combines traditional face-to-face learning with online and electronic education materials.

sections.title: Closed-loop system
sections.text: An automated insulin delivery system that continuously monitors blood glucose levels and automatically adjusts insulin dosing in real time, reducing the need for manual insulin administration.

sections.title: Decentralized clinical trials
sections.text: Trials that are conducted without in-person contact, utilizing remote methods for participant recruitment, medication delivery and data collection. Diagnostic decision-support systems (DDSSs). Software that helps patients and health-care professionals interpret medical data to initiate appropriate diagnostic work-up and ultimately generate accurate and timely diagnoses.

sections.title: Digital divide
sections.text: In health care, refers to the disparity between individuals who have both access to digital health technologies and the necessary skills to use them effectively, and those who lack either or both.

sections.title: Key performance indicators
sections.text: Quantifiable metrics used to assess progress in relation to specific objectives, thereby guiding strategic decision-making.

sections.title: Large language models
sections.text: (LLMs). An advanced AI system trained on vast amounts data to interpret, generate and manipulate human language.

sections.title: Patient self-sampling
sections.text: The process through which patients collect their own biological specimens (such as saliva or blood) for diagnostic or monitoring purposes.

sections.title: Patient-initiated follow-up
sections.text: A care delivery model that enables patients to reach out to the clinic as needed, rather than attending regularly scheduled follow-up appointments.

sections.title: Plan-Do-Check-Act cycle
sections.text: A continuous improvement process used to systematically plan, implement, evaluate and refine changes to enhance processes or products.

sections.title: Prompt engineering
sections.text:
The process of designing and refining input queries or instructions to effectively guide the output of LLMs and other AI systems.

The Nonadoption, Abandonment, Scale-up, Spread, and Sustainability (NASSS) framework A tool designed to assess and guide the implementation, scaling and sustainability of complex health and care technologies by examining challenges across seven domains.

sections.title: Virtual visits
sections.text: An example of asynchronous telehealth that involves a health-care professional reviewing medical information that has been stored and forwarded by the patient; also known as an electronic visit (e-visit).

employing a participatory design  129, 131  . Participatory design is a methodology that actively engages all relevant stakeholders to ensure a strong value proposition and usability and, most importantly, to foster ownership of DHT implementation changes 131 . Participatory design typically involves three overlapping phases: needs assessment, design and testing, with multiple iterations and feedback loops. Gathering qualitative feedback from stakeholders is vital for gaining a comprehensive understanding of both barriers and facilitators of DHT implementation.

Collaborative efforts are key to effectively navigating and leveraging the rapidly evolving digital health landscape. Nevertheless, there is no universal solution and tailored strategies are essential to addressing the unique needs and conditions of each DHT implementation scenario. Various local, national and international task forces have formed to exchange experiences, to set up hands-on workshops, and to provide initial recommendations  60, 111, [132] [133] [134]  and research agendas 111 to steer future initiatives. The NHS Rheumatology Digital Playbook provides a collection of inspiring case studies depicting successful digital transformation in rheumatology. The Digital Rheumatology Network exemplifies such collaboration, serving as an international consortium dedicated to promoting the adoption of digital health in rheumatology. This network supports the field through the provision of educational resources and regular face-to-face and virtual congresses and by encouraging research and innovation with start-up and research awards.

sections.title: Conclusions
sections.text:
The digital health era holds transformative potential for rheumatology, offering innovative solutions to longstanding challenges in patient care and system efficiency. DHTs can be implemented along the entire patient pathway to improve diagnostics, treatment and monitoring and to empower patients. AI-based automation of workflows has the potential to substantially reduce bureaucratic burdens for all stakeholders involved, decrease screen time and promote more meaningful human interactions. Implementation of a digital-first hybrid stepped-care strategy and decision-support systems promise to facilitate a shift towards a more personalized, predictive and participatory health-care model. However, the successful integration of these technologies into routine clinical care will require overcoming substantial barriers, including regulatory hurdles, reimbursement, and the need for widespread professional training and patient education. By sharing lessons learned and fostering collaboration, rheumatologists can accelerate the transition and fully harness the potential of digital health to meet growing demands.

Fig.2| Transformation of care delivery through digital health. Health care could be transformed via a progressive transition from traditional information gathering and care delivery (lower left), characterized by episodic, in-person visits that are reliant on health-care professionals for data collection and treatment provision, to a digitally supported, patient-centred care model (upper right). Examples across the transition spectrum include traditional in-person consultations (lower left), virtual consultations (middle) and sensor-based monitoring in combination with smartphone-based digital therapeutics (top right). In this evolving paradigm, patients gain autonomy, conduct self-assessments and receive continuous therapy support, anywhere and anytime. The burden of care on patients and health-care professionals is reduced by sensor-based continuous measurements and automated patient treatment support.

Fig.3| Digital-first hybrid stepped-care model. a, An overview of a hybrid monitoring approach compared with traditional face-to-face visits. b, The five levels of patient monitoring and escalation of care. In traditional follow-up, patients attend synchronous, periodic, pre-planned, face-to-face consultations, which can result in overlooked disease flares and adverse effects. Quick access to answers and appointments during flares is challenging. Conversely, digitally supported hybrid patient follow-up fosters a proactive, continuous and personalized care approach.
